page.title: 06THE ANIMALS OF MID-WALES
page.content: The most typical "Welsh" animal in the district is the polecat which, just after the 2nd. World War, was more or less restricted to Cardiganshire but is now reported as far east as the outskirts of Birmingham. The otter is a distant relative of the polecat and its stronghold in England and Wales is now the upper Wye and upper Severn catchments. It is therefore pleasing to note that it has bred within the last few years on this part of the Wye. Foxes are plentiful and kept in check by hunting which probably kills half the population each year. Badgers on the other hand are protected by law and found in several local woodlands. There has been concern that they may be carriers of bovine tuberculosis, but no badgers in Powys have been found to be infected. There are bats in Cwmbach Church.
